Award.AwardTitle: Participation of Qualified Oceanographers from Developing Countries in International Scientific Activities
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funds to the Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research (SCOR) for a long-standing program of travel assistance to qualified and active oceanographic researchers from developing countries and nations with economies in transition. SCOR travel grants are awarded to enable such individuals to attend international meetings relevant to their scientific interests and to those of SCOR and the Division of Ocean Sciences of NSF. This ongoing project has become the cornerstone of SCOR's efforts to provide assistance to marine scientists in the third world and, more recently in Russia and Eastern Europe.

Broader Impacts

The impacts of this activity extend beyond the ocean sciences into other scientific topics by stimulating scientific progress in developing countries. In many cases, personal connections and collaborations that can result from contacts made through these travel grants can have long-lasting effects both in international activities as well as in the developing country?s science communities as the individuals involved rise through the ranks of science and science policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant entitled "Participation of Qualified Oceanographers from Developing Countries in International Scientific Activities" was designed to increase networking between ocean scientists from the United States and both developing countries and countries with economies in transition (primarily Russia and Eastern Europe). One beneift of this increased networking is that capacity for ocean science is built in developing countries.  It is often difficult for U.S. scientists to make contact with scientists from such countries because travel funding is limited for scientists from many developing countries and countries experiencing economic hardships. This lack of contact impedes efforts of U.S. scientists to learn about ocean systems in other parts of the world. Activities under this grant had three major purposes.  First, travel support was provided to 128 individuals from 35 different countries to attend 35 different ocean science meetings and summer schools. Through such participation, scientific knowledge is disseminated between the developed and developed world, new partnerships are formed, and techniques for ocean science are transferred from developed to developing countries. The second aspect of this grant is a joint program of fellowships in techniques of ocean observations between the Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research and the Partnership for Observation of the Global Oceans.  Eight individuals received fellowships from this grant to learn techniques of ocean observation, which will help speed implementation of the Global Ocean Observing System. The third aspect of this grant is the SCOR Visiting Scholars program.  The grant was used to support travel expenses of 8 SCOR Visiting Scholars, who are individuals who donate their time to teach and mentor ocean science students in developing countries.  The host institutions in the developing countries provide housing for the SCOR Visiting Scholar and often pay for other expenses.
